revision.text:
The system on [[Education in Austria#Higher education|higher education in Austria]] distinguishes between '''federal universities''' (Universitäten), '''private universities''' (Privatuniversitäten) and '''universities of applied science''' (Fachhochschulen). The three types are based on different laws. One of the main differences (but not the only) is funding. Two institutions in Lower Austria have a special legal status. Since 2012 the Agentur für Qualitätssicherung und Akkreditierung Austria (AQ Austria) is responsible for [[educational accreditation]] of universities, except paedagogic.
List of [[university|universities]] in [[Austria]]:
==By state==
===[[Burgenland]]=== Private university: *[[European Peace University]] in [[Stadtschlaining]] University of applied sciences: *[[University of Applied Sciences Burgenland]] in [[Eisenstadt]] and [[Pinkafeld]]
===[[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]]=== Federal university: *[[Alpen-Adria-Universität Klagenfurt]] University of applied science: * [[Carinthia University of Applied Sciences]] ([http://www.fh-kaernten.at/en.html]) in [[Spittal an der Drau]], [[Klagenfurt]], [[Villach]] and [[Feldkirchen in Kärnten]]
===[[Lower Austria]]=== University for continuing education: *[[Danube University Krems]] in [[Krems an der Donau|Krems]] Private universities: *[[Benedict XVI Philosophical-Theological University]], [[Heiligenkreuz, Lower Austria|Heiligenkreuz]] *[[Danube Private University]] in [[Krems an der Donau|Krems]] *[[New Design University]] in [[Sankt Pölten]] * Karl Landsteiner University of Health Sciences in [[Krems an der Donau|Krems]] Universities of applied science: *[[IMC University of Applied Sciences Krems]] in [[Krems an der Donau|Krems]] *[[University of Applied Sciences Wiener Neustadt|University of Applied Sciences]] in [[Wiener Neustadt]] *[[St. Pölten University of Applied Sciences]] in [[Sankt Pölten]] *[[Theresian Military Academy]] in [[Wiener Neustadt]] Not a university, but an institute with PhD programmes: *[[Institute of Science and Technology Austria]] in [[Klosterneuburg]]
===[[Salzburg]]=== Federal universities: *[[University of Salzburg]] *[[Mozarteum University Salzburg]] Private universities: *[[Paracelsus Medical University]] in [[Salzburg]] *[[Alma Mater Europaea]] in [[Salzburg]] and campuses in other countries *[[Private University Seeburg Castle]] in [[Seekirchen am Wallersee]] University of applied sciences: *[[Salzburg University of Applied Sciences]] in [[Puch bei Hallein]] and in [[Kuchl]]
===[[Styria]]=== Federal universities: *[[University of Graz]] *[[Graz University of Technology]] *[[Medical University of Graz]] *[[University of Leoben]] *[[University of Music and Performing Arts Graz]] Universities of applied science: *[[FH Joanneum]] in [[Graz]] *[[Campus 02 University of Applied Sciences]] in [[Graz]] university college: *[[University College of Teacher Education Styria]]

{{Like resume|date=February 2017}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Manfred F.R. Kets de Vries | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_place = [[The Netherlands]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Paris]], France | nationality = {{Flagicon|Netherlands}} Dutch | ethnicity = | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[University of Amsterdam]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | alma_mater = | employer = [[INSEAD]] | occupation = [[Professor]] | home_town = | website = {{URL|http://www.kdvi.com/}} | footnotes = ''[[Order of Orange-Nassau|Officier in de Orde van Oranje Nassau]]'' (Netherlands) }} '''Manfred F.R. Kets de Vries''' is a Dutch management scholar and psychoanalyst, Professor of [[leadership development]] and [[organizational change]] at [[INSEAD]], and consultant.{{cite web|title=Manfred Kets de Vries|url=https://www.insead.edu/faculty-research/faculty/manfred-f-r-kets-de-vries/|publisher=INSEAD|accessdate=30 May 2018}} His work focuses on leadership and the dynamics of individual and organizational change.{{cite web|last=Coutu|first=Diane|title=Putting Leaders on the Couch|url=https://hbr.org/2004/01/putting-leaders-on-the-couch|publisher=Harvard Business Review|accessdate=23 September 2013}} Specifically, Kets de Vries explores the interface between management theory, psychoanalysis, psychotherapy, executive coaching and evolutionary psychology. The [[American Psychological Association]] awarded him the Harry and Miriam Levinson Award in 2001 for his contributions to the field of consultation and in 2009, Kets de Vries was rated amongst the Top 50 Thinkers in Management.{{cite web|title=The Thinkers50 Ranking 2009|url=http://www.thinkers50.com/t50-ranking/2009-2/|publisher=Thinkers 50|accessdate=3 April 2015}} == Biography == Kets de Vries received a master's degree in Economics in 1966) from the [[University of Amsterdam]]; an International Teachers Program certificate in 1967, his [[M.B.A.]] in 1968, and his [[Doctor of Business Administration|D.B.A.]] in 1970 from [[Harvard Business School]]. He also received training from the Canadian Psychoanalytic Society, where he has been a member since 1982. Kets de Vries has held professorships at [[McGill University]], the ''[[HEC Montréal|École des Hautes Études Commerciales]]'', Montreal, and [[Harvard Business School]], and has lectured at management institutions around the world. He is a founding member of the [[International Society for the Psychoanalytic Study of Organizations]], of which he became, in 2009, a Lifetime Distinguished Member,{{cite web|title=ISPSO Distinguished Member|url=https://www.ispso.org/the-field:distinguished|publisher=ISPSO|accessdate=3 April 2015}} a member of the International Psychoanalytic Association and a corresponding member of the Paris Psychoanalytical Society. Kets de Vries has won numerous awards for his work in the leadership field. In 2005, he was the first non-American to receive the International Leadership Award for "his contributions to the classroom and the board room".{{cite web|title=Distinguished Leadership Award|url=http://www.ila-net.org/Awards/DLA/index.htm|publisher=ILA|accessdate=3 April 2015}} In 2008, he was given the Lifetime Achievement Award (the Leadership Legacy Project) of the International Leadership Association, being viewed as one of the world’s six founding professionals in the development of leadership as a field and discipline.{{cite web|title=Lifetime Achievement Award|url=http://www.ila-net.org/LeadershipLegacy/Manfred_Kets_de_Vries.html|publisher=ILA|accessdate=30 May 2018}} In 2010 the Dutch Psychoanalytic Institute in the Netherlands presented him with the Freud Memorial Award, in acknowledgement of his work on the interface between psychoanalysis and organizations. In October 2011, Kets de Vries was awarded the ''Doctor Honoris Causa'' title from IEDC Bled School of Management for his "outstanding contribution to creation and integration of knowledge and leadership development for a better world".{{cite web|title=IEDC Honorary Professorship and Doctor Honoris Causa Recipients|url=http://www.iedc.si/about-iedc/general-information|publisher=IEDC|accessdate=3 April 2015}} In October 2012, Kets de Vries received an Honorary Doctorate from the Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration (RANEPA) at IBS-Moscow.{{cite web|title=Mysticism of Leadership: Creating Authentic Organizations|url=https://ibda.ranepa.ru/about/master-klassy/news1928.html|publisher=RANEPA|accessdate=7 June 2018}}In 2013, Kets de Vries gave a TEDx Talk on the subject of leadership dysfunction.{{cite web|title=From Hero to Zero: Why leaders turn bad|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6VEypCeMCIE|publisher=TED Talks|accessdate=30 May 2018}} In 2016, Kets de Vries was the first beneficiary of the INSEAD Dominique Héau Award for “Inspiring Educational Excellence.”{{cite web|url=https://faculty.insead.edu/in-memoriam-dominique-heau/honouring|title=Dominique Heau Award|publisher=INSEAD}} In 2016, he was awarded the German Life Achievement Award der Weiterbildungsbranche, a prize offered by the German further education sector.{{cite web|url=https://www.managerseminare.de/managerSeminare_TV/Manfred-Kets-de-Vries-mit-Life-Achievement-Award-ausgezeichnet,244569|title=Life Achievement Award Preisträger |publisher=}} == Work == Kets de Vries is the founder of INSEAD's Global Leadership Centre, program director of INSEAD's top [[management]] seminar, "The Challenge of Leadership: Creating Reflective Leaders" and the scientific director of the "Consulting and Coaching for Change; Executive Master's Program". He is also the founder of the Kets de Vries Institute, a consulting firm. He is a distinguished visiting professor at [[ESMT European School of Management and Technology]] in Berlin.[http://www.esmt.org/manfred-f-r-kets-de-vries Kets de Vries (ESMT)] ==Selected Works== *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | last2 = Miller | first2=D. | year = 1984 | title = The Neurotic Organization: Diagnosing and Changing Counterproductive Styles of Management | publisher = Jossey-Bass | ISBN = 0-87589-606-5 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=B8G3AAAAIAAJ }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2006 | title = The Leadership Mystique: a user's manual for the human enterprise | publisher = FT Press | ISBN = 0-273-65620-1 | url = https://books.google.fr/books/about/The_Leadership_Mystique.html?id=U1Ya7__jI4AC&redir_esc=y }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2006 | title = The Leader on the Couch: A Clinical Approach to Changing People and Organizations | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Ltd. | ISBN = 9985-9757-4-X | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=aaOVGQAACAAJ }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | last2 = Carlock | first2=Randel S. | last3 = Florent-Treacy | first3=Elizabeth | year = 2007 | title = Family Business on the Couch: A Psychological Perspective | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Ltd | pages = 324 | ISBN = 978-0-470-51671-3 | url = http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470516712.html }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2009 | title = Sex, Money, Happiness and Death: The Quest for Authenticity | publisher = Palgrave | pages = 264 | ISBN = 0-230-57792-X | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fPTVOwAACAAJ }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2009 | title = Reflections on Character and Leadership | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Ltd | pages = 366 | ISBN = 978-0-470-74242-6 | url = http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470742429.html }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2009 | title = Reflections on Leadership and Career Development | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Ltd | pages = 264 | ISBN = 978-0-470-74246-4 | url = http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470742461.html }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2011 | title = The Hedgehog Effect: The Secrets of Building High Performance Teams | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Ltd | pages = 316 | ISBN = 978-1-119-97336-2 | url = http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1119973368.html }} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2016 | title = Telling Fairy Tales in the Boardroom | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | ISBN = 978-1-137-56272-2 | url = http://www.palgrave.com/de/book/9781137562722 |location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2017 | title = Riding the Leadership Rollercoaster | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | ISBN = 978-1-137-38232-0 | url = https://www.palgrave.com/de/book/9783319451619 |location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} *{{cite book | last = Florent-Treacy | first=Elizabeth | year = 2017 | title = Manfred F. R. Kets de Vries: Playing the Morosophe in The Palgrave Handbook of Organizational Change Thinkers | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | ISBN = 978-3-319-52877-9 | url = https://www.palgrave.com/gp/book/9783319528779 |location=|pages=|quote=|via=|first2=Konstantin|last2=Korotov|first3=Caroline|last3=Rook}} *{{cite book | last = Kets de Vries | first=Manfred F. R. | year = 2018 | title = Down the Rabbit Hole of Leadership: Leadership Pathology of Everyday Life | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | ISBN = 978-3-319-92462-5 | url = https://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9783319924618 |location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{wikiquote}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kets De Vries, Manfred F.R.}} [[Category:Life coaches]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:INSEAD faculty]] [[Category:People from Fontainebleau]] [[Category:Dutch expatriates in France]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Orange-Nassau]] [[Category:Leadership scholars]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:University of Amsterdam alumni]] [[Category:European School of Management and Technology faculty]]

{{about||the Ukrainian politician|Mykhailo Brodskyy|the Israeli diplomat|Michael Brodsky (diplomat)}} {{Infobox writer | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1948|8|2|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, Editor | notableworks = ''[[Xman]]'',
''[[*** (novel)|***]]'' | movement = [[Postmodern literature|Postmodern]] | nationality = American | influences = [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]],Many reviews [[Marcel Proust]],Brodsky article on Svevo [[#Criticism]] [[Franz Kafka]], [[Italo Svevo]], [[Samuel Beckett]] | influenced = | website = {{URL|http://www.webdelsol.com/4Walls8Windows/Michael_Brodsky/}} }} '''Michael Mark Brodsky''' (born Aug 2, 1948This is taken from ''World Authors, 1995-2000'', ''CANRS'' 147, ''DLB'' 244. Brodsky's first two books give his birth year as 1951, later books give 1948.See also ''CANRS'' 147 and ''DLB'' 244, cited above.) is a scientific/medical editor, novelist, playwright, and short story writer. He is best known for his novels, and for his translation of [[Samuel Beckett]]'s ''[[Eleutheria (play)|Eleuthéria]]''. ==Personal background== Michael Brodsky was born in [[New York City]], the son of Martin and Marian Brodsky. He attended the [[Bronx High School of Science]].''Detour'', author information He received a 1969 BA from [[Columbia College, Columbia University|Columbia University]], taught math and science in New York for a year, attended [[Case Western Reserve University]] [http://casemed.case.edu/ medical school] for two years, then taught French and English in Cleveland until 1975. Brodsky returned to New York City in 1976, working as an editor for the Institute for Research on Rheumatic Diseases. He married Laurence Lacoste.11/28/1976, as given in ''DLB'' 244 and ''CANRS'' 147 They are the parents of two children, Joseph Matthew and Matthew Daniel. From 1985-1991, Brodsky was an editor with [[Springer-Verlag]]. After 1991, he was with the [[United Nations]].all other information, these two paragraphs, is from ''World Authors 1995-2000'' or ''DLB'' 244 or ''CANRS'' 147 Brodsky lives on [[Roosevelt Island]].''CANRS'' 147, and [http://www.zeek.net/804fiction/ Zeek magazine]. ==Unpublished works== The following list of "Books by Michael Brodsky" appeared in ''[[Project (novella)|Project]] and other short pieces'': :''Bulletins'', novel (1969-70) :''Haven'', novel (1972-73) *''[[Circuits (novel)|Circuits]]'', novel (1974, revised 1980-81) *''[[Detour (Brodsky novel)|Detour]]'', novel (1975) :''Flesh is Flesh'', novel (1976) :''Street Lesions'', play (1977) *''Dose Center'', play (1977) *''Terrible Sunlight'', play (1978) :''Theme and Variations'', novel (1979) *''Night of the Chair'', play (1980) :''Four Nephews'', dialogue (1980) *''[[Wedding Feast]] and Two Novellas'' (1982) :''Isaac Luria'', novel (1982) The entries with a bullet-point have been published, or, in the case of the plays, performed. All novels but the last were named in a German-language newspaper article on Brodsky.{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/1983/38/michael-brodsky-der-tatbestand-und-seine-huelle|title=Michael Brodsky "Der Tatbestand und seine Hülle"|publisher=Die Zeit|date=September 9, 1983|accessdate=November 1, 2012}} ''Flesh is Flesh'' was named as forthcoming on the dustjacket of the first edition of ''Detour''. ==Published and performed works== ===Novels=== *''[[Detour (Brodsky novel)|Detour]]'', 1978 **republished, expanded, [[Del Sol Press]], 2003 * ''[[Circuits (novel)|Circuits]]'', 1983 * ''[[Xman]]'', [[Four Walls Eight Windows]], 1987 * ''[[Dyad (novel)|Dyad]]'', Four Walls Eight Windows, 1989 * ''[[*** (novel)|***]]'', Four Walls Eight Windows, 1994 * ''[[We Can Report Them]]'', Four Walls Eight Windows, 1999 ====Forthcoming==== *''Invidicum'', an excerpt appears in ''Review of Contemporary Fiction'', 31.1, Spring 2011 (the Failure issue), with this headnote: ::Brodsky's novel-in-progress, ''Invidicum'', concerns an experimental drug for "Envy Disease," and the group involved in its clinical trials. ===Shorter fiction=== * ''[[Wedding Feast]]'', 1981 * ''[[Project (novella)|Project]]'', 1982 ** contains "The Envelope of the Given", also published separately in German translation by [[Jürg Laederach]], 1982 * ''[[X in Paris]]'', 1988 * ''[[Three Goat Songs]]'', 1991 * ''[[Southernmost (novella)|Southernmost]]'', 1996 * ''[[Limit Point]]'', 2007 ===Plays=== Never published, these plays were performed [[Off-Off-Broadway]] in brief runs:the first three are listed in contemporary ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' theater listings, the first four in [[New York Times]] theater listings, all are listed in ''DLB'' 244 * ''Terrible Sunlight'', 1980 ** "An experimental work, ... utilizing various visual media ...."''New York'', 4/21/1980, p. 27. * ''Dose Center'', 1990 ** The "play probes the interaction between two men, their fellows and keepers, within the confines of a mental institution."''New York'', 2/26/1990, p. 155. * ''Night of the Chair'', 1990 ** The play "shows two figures playing out their life-or-death struggle around a single simple prop."''New York'', 12/10/1990, p. 128. * ''Six Scenes: A Barracks Brawl'', 1994 * ''The Anti-Muse'', reading 1996, performance 2000 Apparently never performed, these plays were published in ''Project'': * ''Packet Piece'', 1982 * ''No Packet Piece'', 1982 ===Translation=== * ''[[Eleutheria (play)|Eleuthéria]]'', by [[Samuel Beckett]], written 1947, suppressed, published 1995 ===Criticism=== *"Svevo: The Artist as Analyzand", ''Review of Existential Psychology and Psychiatry'', 15 no. 2-3 (1977), pp 112–133. *"Toward the Plane of the Sacred: Hafftka’s Great Chain of Being" [http://www.hafftka.com/brodsky/index.html essay] in the [http://www.hafftka.com/hma/index.html catalogue] for [[Michael Hafftka]] "A Retrospective: Large Oils 1985-2003" (2004).Hafftka was the illustrator (cover and some internal) for Brodsky's early fiction, and later for [[Limit Point]]. ==Critical reception== Critical reception to Brodsky's work has been strongly polarized, with the praise putting him in the company of some of the greatest writers, and with the rejections being openly insulting. ===Highly positive=== {{quote|His novels, plays and short story collections have been likened, by the mainstream press, to the work of Beckett, Joyce, Kafka, Proust, Dostoevski and Swift, as well as Barth, Pynchon, Barthelme and Burroughts. I would add [[Thomas Bernhard]] and [[Italo Svevo]], for reasons of style and the formidable, original talent their texts exhibit.|Judith Upjohn|"#$%!: review of ***",''American Book Review'', v16, no5, Dec-Feb 1994-5}} {{quote|It should be obvious to serious readers ... that Brodsky ... is a sensitive, original, and insightful writer, one of the best produced by this country in the last 30 years.|[[Harvey Pekar]]|[[Village Voice]], "An American Revisionary", review of ''Detour'' re-issue, 8/19/2003}} ===Highly negative=== {{quote|His latest deconstructionist experiment fails miserably, consisting almost entirely of the pathetic projections, obsessions, rationalizations, and delusions of a character we are not given the slightest reason to care about. A few scholarly avant-gardists, confused compulsives, and bibliomasochists will love this book.|Jim Dwyer, [[California State University, Chico|Cal State Chico]]|''Library Journal'', review of ''[[Three Goat Songs]]'', 1991}} {{quote|It would be nice if the hapless reader didn't have to reach for the nearest bottle of Excedrin or take a nap between pages or could actually connect with a character or two in any of these frustratingly opaque stories.|[[Charles Salzberg]]|''[[New York Times]]'', review of ''Southernmost and other stories'', 3/9/1997}} ==Further reading== A short biography, and brief summaries of Brodsky's longer fiction and critical reception can be found here: *Herman, Peter G., "Michael Brodsky", ''World Authors, 1995-2000'' Ed. Clifford Thompson and Mari Rich. New York: H. W. Wilson Company (2003). pp 113–115. *''Contemporary Authors New Revision Series'', vol 147 (2006) pp 56–8. Brief summaries of his shorter fiction, critical reception, and quotations from Brodsky on his own fiction, can be found here: *Hawley, John C., "Michael Brodsky (2 August 1948-)", ''American Short-Story Writers Since World War II'', Fourth Series. Ed. Patrick Meanor and Joseph McNicholas. ''Dictionary of Literary Biography'' Vol. 244. Detroit: Gale Group, 2001. pp 34–39. Online [http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/DLBC_Online/upenn_main/BK1559815005 here]. ==References== ''CANRS'' refers to ''Contemporary Authors New Revision Series'', and ''DLB'' refers to ''Dictionary of Literary Biography''. Full citations are above. {{reflist}} {{Michael Brodsky}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brodsky, Michael}} [[Category:American editors]] [[Category:Postmodernists]] [[Category:English teachers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1948 births]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox university | name = Minsk Radioengineering College | native_name = Минский радиотехнический колледж | native_name_lang = ru | image = | image_size = 250px | image_alt = Minsk Radioengineering College in 2011 | caption = MRC at 2011 | latin_name = Collegium Radioipsum Minskiensis | other_name = | former_names = Minsk Radioegnineering Technical School
Minsk State Higher Radioengineering College | motto = | motto_lang = | mottoeng = | type = Radioengineering | established = | closed = | founder = | parent = | endowment = | budget = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chairperson = | chancellor = | president = | vice-president = | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor= | principal = | dean = | director = Sergey Nikolayevich Ankuda | head_label = | head = | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = 1662 | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | address = 220005, Minsk, Nezavisimosti ave., 62. | city = [[Minsk]] | state = | province = | country = [[Belarus]] | postcode = 220005 | language = Russian, [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]] | sporting_affiliations = | website = {{URL|mrk-bsuir.by}} | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Minsk Radioengineering College''' ({{lang-be|Мі́нскі Радыётэхні́чны Кале́дж, Mínski Radyjotechníčny Kaliédž}}, {{lang-ru|link=no|Минский Радиотехнический колледж, Minskiy Radiotekhnicheskiy kolledzh}}) is an educational Institution of the [[Republic of Belarus]]. Training with secondary special education on the basis of basic education. == History == In July 2, 1960 on the basis of the [[BSSR]] Council of Ministers Resolution № 383 "''Minsk Radio Engineering College''" was established. Having started its activities in the period of formation and development of the electronic industry in the Republic of Belarus, Radio Technical College is gradually transformed into a top college.[http://mrk-bsuir.by/ru/content/istoriya-mrk История МРК] In 1 September 1960 200 students started their studies in the newly opened Minsk Radio Technical School, the establishment of which was determined by the development of industrial production, which identified the need of the republic in skilled technical personnel. The first set of students was carried out in the field: *Electronic computers, instruments and devices *Radioapparatostroenie *Manufacture of electronic components and materials *Programming for High-speed mathematical machines 22 teachers are trained professionals for full-time and correspondence courses. Among them were veterans of the Great Patriotic War, including – Hero of the Soviet Union Ivan Eliseevich Sambuc. In 1991, there was an order of the Ministry of Public Education of the Republic of Belarus №144 from 17.06.91. "On the transformation of an experiment in Minsk Radio Technical School in the school of a new type, the college". In 1995, the college was again reorganized and gained new status and name "The Minsk State Higher Radio Technical College". In November 1, 2015 Minsk State Higher Radio Technical College transformed into UO BSUIR branch "Minsk Radioengineering College". == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://mrk-bsuir.by/ Сайт МРК] * [http://mrk-bsuir.by/ru/ Сайт МРК] {{ref-ru}} {{coord|53.9192|N|27.5928|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1960]] [[Category:Education in Minsk]]

revision.text:
The '''National Math and Science Initiative (NMSI)''' is a non-profit organization based in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], that launched in 2007. Its mission is to improve student performance in the subjects of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) in the [[United States]]. It attempts to do this by scaling up local academic programs to a national level.
==History of the Initiative== In 2005, the National Academies commissioned a report titled “Rising Above the Gathering Storm” which asserts that student achievement in the subjects of math and science has declined in the United States, while other countries have increased their student achievement scores in the same subject areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www7.nationalacademies.org/ocga/testimony/gathering_storm_energizing_and_employing_america2.asp |title=Rising Above The Gathering Storm: Energizing and Employing America for a Brighter Economic Future}}</ref> The report recommended the creation of a non-profit organization to help marshal private sector support to help improve math and science education in the United States. Several authors of the report partnered with Peter O’Donnell Jr. to meet this need, effectively establishing NMSI’s board of directors and committing to bring both the [[UTeach]] and NMSI’s College Readiness program (formerly known as NMSI’s Comprehensive AP Program and the Advanced Placement Training and Incentive Program (APTIP)) to scale nationally. ExxonMobil invested $125 million to launch the effort,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.exxonmobil.com/en/community/math-and-science/national-math-and-science-initiative/overview?parentId=bad0c112-6677-4324-bd39-c28aa7ed3237 |title=National Math and Science Initiative (ExonnMobil)}}</ref> which was later supplemented by an additional $125 million from corporations, foundations, individual donors and government agencies – creating an effective public-private partnership model that continues to sustain the organization today.
==NMSI's Programs== NMSI has expanded three programs to a national scale: [http://www.nms.org/Programs/CollegeReadinessProgram.aspx NMSI’s College Readiness Program], [http://www.nms.org/Programs/LayingtheFoundationProgram.aspx NMSI’s Laying the Foundation Program], and [http://www.nms.org/Education/UTeach.aspx NMSI's UTeach Expansion Program].
===NMSI’s College Readiness Program=== NMSI’s College Readiness Program is a three-year program in which teachers go through rigorous professional development to better prepare themselves and their students for Advanced Placement Exams. The prototype for NMSI’s program, Advanced Placement Strategies (APS) was launched as a public-private partnership in the Dallas area in 1995 by a group of local businessmen committed to education reform. The goal of the APS program was to improve college readiness and encourage STEM studies for underserved Texas public high school students by increasing participation and performance in AP math, science and English courses. Texas schools in their first year of the APS program increased their exam participation by 198 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-109shrg26426/html/CHRG-109shrg26426.htm |title=PROTECTING AMERICA'S COMPETITIVE EDGE ACT (S. 2198): HELPING K-12 STUDENTS LEARN MATH AND SCIENCE BETTER}}</ref>
In the 2008-2009 school year, NMSI replicated the APS program as the Advanced Placement Training and Incentive Program (APTIP) and in its first year, the program increased enrollment in AP courses by nearly 70 percent, including a 122 percent increase among African American and Hispanic students. The number of passing AP math, science, and English exams also increased by 52 percent, which was nine times the national average; for African American and Hispanic students, the increase in passing AP scores was 71.5 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100830005772/en/National-Math-Science-Initiative%E2%80%99s-Year-Results-Boost#.Uv1YHvldV8E |title=National Math and Science Initiative’s Year Two Results Boost Student Achievement by 98 Percent, Opening Doors to College}}</ref>
On September 1, 2012, APS officially merged with NMSI to bring this program to scale throughout the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/advanced-placement-strategies-joins-national-math-and-science-168435816.html |title=Advanced Placement Strategies Joins National Math and Science}}</ref> More than 50,000 students are now enrolled in the NMSI College Readiness Program, and it is currently being implemented in more than 550 schools in 22 states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/students-in-national-math-and-science-initiative-program-outperform-peers-on-advanced-placement-exams-for-fifth-consecutive-year-221483841.html |title=Students in National Math and Science Initiative Program Outperform Peers on Advanced Placement Exams for Fifth Consecutive Year}}</ref>
The most recent results show a continuing trend of student improvement. Over the life cycle of the NMSI program, the number of average passing scores on AP math, science and English exams increased by 144 percent, compared to 23.2 percent nationally. The average three-year increase in the number of passing math, science and English scores among minorities enrolled in the NMSI program is 219 percent compared to the national average of 48.5 percent. The number of average passing scores for females enrolled in the NMSI program increased by 87 percent, compared to 8.7 percent nationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nms.org/Blog/TabId/58/PostId/163/students-in-national-math-and-science-initiative-program-outperform-peers-on-advanced-placement-exams-for-fifth-consecutive-year.aspx |title=Students in National Math and Science Initiative Program Outperform Peers on Advanced Placement Exams for Fifth Consecutive Year}}</ref>
In 2010, the organization received funding from the Lockheed Martin Corporation to launch the AP program in schools serving military bases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100521005152/en/Lockheed-Martin-Corporation-Partners-National-Math-Science |title=Lockheed Martin Corporation Partners with the National Math and Science Initiative in Support of Children in Military Families}}</ref> In April 2011, First Lady Michelle Obama and Dr. Jill Biden announced the expansion of the program as part of their national Joining Forces initiative, which aims to provide support and resources to military personnel and their families in the areas of employment, housing, health care, education, etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.massinsight.org/news/213/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419025055/http://www.massinsight.org/news/213/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-04-19 |title=WHITE HOUSE CELEBRATES ANNIVERSARY OF JOINING FORCES, COMMENDS NMSI’S INITIATIVE FOR MILITARY FAMILIES }}</ref> Mrs. Obama and Dr. Biden made the announcement at a community event at Fountain-Fort Carson High School in Fountain, Colo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox21news.com/news/story.aspx?id=605544#.UnloP_nkvO4 |title=First Lady visits school near Fort Carson}}</ref> As of January 2014, NMSI’s College Readiness Program is being implemented in 71 schools serving military families in 18 states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nms.org/Blog/TabId/58/PostId/220/aberdeen-high-school-awarded-the-national-math-and-science-initiative-school-of-the-year.aspx |title=Aberdeen High School Awarded National Math and Science Initiative "School of the Year"}}</ref>
===NMSI's Laying the Foundation Program=== In January 2012, NMSI merged with Laying the Foundation, an organization which focused on professional development for math, science, and English teachers, grades 6-12.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111216005087/en/Laying-Foundation-Joins-National-Math-Science-Initiative |title=Laying the Foundation Joins National Math and Science Initiative}}</ref> After the merge, NMSI’s Laying the Foundation teacher training program was expanded to include training for elementary teachers, grades 3-5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nms.org/Blog/TabId/58/PostId/128/freddie-kendrick-talks-elementary-education.aspx |title=NMSI’s Freddie Kendrick Talks Elementary Education}}</ref> In 2012, NMSI was selected to work with the Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers (PARCC) consortium to lead Common Core State Standards training in 22 states and create the Educator Leader Cadre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nmsi-awarded-43-million-contract-to-lead-parcc-educator-leader-cadres-159403165.html |title=NMSI Awarded $4.3 Million Contract to Lead PARCC Educator Leader Cadres}}</ref>
In August 2013, NMSI received a $248,760 grant from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to develop a series of web-based training modules for teachers who have attended NMSI’s Laying the Foundation Program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/online-learning-modules-will-play-a-big-role-in-common-core-implementation-across-the-us-219405611.html |title=Online Learning Modules Will Play a Big Role in Common Core Implementation Across the U.S.}}</ref>
===NMSI's UTeach Expansion Program=== The [[UTeach]] Program originated at The University of Texas at Austin in 1997, enabling students who are majoring in math, science, or computer science to receive full teaching certification without adding time or cost to their degrees. The national replication process is directed by NMSI in conjunction with the [[UTeach Institute]].
The NMSI-supported replication of the UTeach program for preparing teachers was launched in 2008 in 13 universities in nine states (Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Pennsylvania, and Texas).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uteach-institute.org/images/uploads/implementation_summary_c1yr2_natl.pdf |title=National Replication of the UTeach Secondary STEM Teacher Preparation Program Implementation Highlights, Cohort 1, Year 2 (2009-2010) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506015641/http://www.uteach-institute.org/images/uploads/implementation_summary_c1yr2_natl.pdf |archivedate=2014-05-06 |df= }}</ref>
On Jan. 6, 2010, President Barack Obama mentioned the UTeach program at a White House education event, saying, “To bring more educators into the classroom, the National Math and Science Initiative is working with Texas Instruments and the Dell Foundation to prepare almost 5,000 new math and science teachers in the next five years -- through a program that allows young people to earn teaching certificates and science degrees at the same time.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/news/2010/01/07/uteach_expansion/ |title=UTeach Expansion Recognized as President Obama Spotlights Importance of Teachers in Improving U.S. Innovation}}</ref> Furthermore, the UTeach Institute projects that 9,000 UTeach program graduates will have impacted 4.8 million secondary STEM students nationwide by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Graduates of UTeach STEM Teacher Preparation Programs|url=http://www.uteach-institute.org/files/uploads/uteach_grad_report_november_2013.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519184840/http://www.uteach-institute.org/files/uploads/uteach_grad_report_november_2013.pdf|archivedate=2014-05-19|df=}}</ref>
On February 4, 2014, it was announced that NMSI is expanding the program to 5 additional universities thanks to a $22.5 million grant from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, bringing the total number of UTeach Replication sites to 40 across 19 states. Another 5 will be added in 2015 through the HHMI funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nms.org/Blog/TabId/58/PostId/224/national-math-and-science-initiative-uteach-institute-and-howard-hughes-medical-institute-announce-national-expansion-of-highly-successful-uteach-program.aspx |title=National Math and Science Initiative, UTeach Institute and Howard Hughes Medical Institute Announce National Expansion of Highly Successful UTeach Program}}</ref>
==Funding== Major support for the National Math and Science Initiative has been provided by the [[Exxon Mobil Corporation]], the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], the [http://www.msdf.org/ Michael & Susan Dell Foundation], and the [[Texas Instruments]] Foundation, with in-kind assistance provided by [[IBM]] and [[Perot Systems]]. Additional funding for [[UTeach]] replication comes from the [http://www.thsp.org/ Texas High School Project], the [http://greatertexasfoundation.org Greater Texas Foundation], the [[Tennessee Higher Education Commission]], the [http://www.tennessee.gov/education/ Tennessee Department of Education], the [[Texas Education Agency]], the Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, and other private philanthropy. With funding from the [[Carnegie Corporation of New York]] and the [http://www.msdf.org/ Michael & Susan Dell Foundation], NMSI also is preparing an alumni network for UTeach graduates.
==Leadership== Matthew Randazzo is the CEO of NMSI. The President is Gregg Fleisher, former President of AP Strategies. NMSI is governed by a board of directors, which is led by Tom Luce, founding CEO of NMSI and the former Assistant Secretary of Education.
