page.title: University of Wales Trinity Saint David

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox University | name = University of Wales Trinity Saint David | native_name = {{lang-cy|Prifysgol Cymru Y Drindod Dewi Sant}} | image_name = Crest of TSD.png | image_size = 200px | caption = [[Coat of arms]] of the University of Wales Trinity Saint David | established = 2010
([[Saint David's College, Lampeter]] founded 1822 and opened 1827; royal charter 1828) | students = {{HESA student population|INSTID=0176}} ({{HESA year}}){{HESA citation}} | undergrad = {{HESA undergraduate population|INSTID=0176}} ({{HESA year}}) | postgrad = {{HESA postgraduate population|INSTID=0176}} ({{HESA year}}) | type = [[Public university|Public]] | endowment = £8.8 million (2015){{cite web | url = http://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/media/uwtsd-website/content-assets/documents/finance/Accounts---Consolidated.pdf | title = Consolidated Financial Statements for the Year to 31 July 2015 | accessdate = 2016-07-12 | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | publisher = University of Wales, Trinity St David| page = 25}} | president = R. Brinley Jones | vice_chancellor = [[Medwin Hughes]] | provost = D. Densil Morgan (Lampeter)
Gwilym Dyfri Jones (Carmarthen) | head_label = [[Visitor]] | head = [[Wyn Evans]], [[Bishop of St David's]] | location = [[Lampeter]], [[Carmarthen]], [[Swansea]], [[London]], [[Cardiff]], [[Birmingham]] | country = [[Wales]] and [[England]], United Kingdom | campus = Multiple campuses | sports = [[Archery]], [[cricket]], [[fencing]], [[Association football|football]], [[hockey]], [[lacrosse]], [[Rugby football|rugby]], [[shooting]] | affiliations = [[University of Wales]]
[[Association of Commonwealth Universities|ACU]]
[[Universities UK]]
[[Cathedrals Group]] | website = {{url|http://www.uwtsd.ac.uk}} | logo = [[File:TSDLogo.png]] }} The '''University of Wales Trinity Saint David''' ({{lang-cy|Prifysgol Cymru Y Drindod Dewi Sant}}) is a multi-campus [[university]] with three main [[campus]]es in [[South West Wales]], in [[Carmarthen]], [[Lampeter]] and [[Swansea]], a fourth campus in [[London]], England, and learning centres in [[Cardiff]], Wales, and [[Birmingham]], England.University of Wales Trinity Saint David (2010); ''Delivering a vision: The Creation of a New University''; Trinity Saint David Trust, p. 3BBC News (2009): [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/mid/8285902.stm ''£14.3m funding for new university'']; accessed 15 June 2010{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/campuses/|title=Campuses, Centres and Locations|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=12 September 2018}} The university came into existence through the merger of the two oldest [[higher education]] institutions in Wales, the [[University of Wales, Lampeter]] (UWL) and [[Trinity University College]] (TUC) in 2010, under Lampeter's royal charter of 1828. In 2011, it was announced that the [[University of Wales]] would also be merged into Trinity Saint David. On 1 August 2013 the university merged with [[Swansea Metropolitan University]]. The Patron of the university is the [[Prince of Wales]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/history/|title=History and Timeline - University of Wales Trinity Saint David|last=UWTSD|first=Web Development Team -|website=www.uwtsd.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-01-18}} the [[Chancellor (education)#Wales|President]] of Trinity Saint David is [[R. Brinley Jones]] and the [[Chancellor (education)#Vice-chancellor|Vice-Chancellor]] is [[Medwin Hughes]]. == History == {{further information|University of Wales, Lampeter#History|Trinity University College#History|Swansea Metropolitan University#History}} The University of Wales Trinity Saint David was formed in July 2010 by the merger of the [[University of Wales, Lampeter]] and [[Trinity University College]], via a supplementary charter to Lampeter's 1828 royal charter.BBC News Report (22 July 2009); [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-10723064 ''College merger sealed by royal charter'']. Retrieved 22 July 2010. In 2008, a [[Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education|QAA]] report on Lampeter concluded that, although the quality of the university's degrees was satisfactory, they had "''limited confidence''" in the institution's [[quality assurance]] procedures and systems.Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education, May 2007; [http://www.qaa.ac.uk/reviews/reports/institutional/UoWLampeter/summary.asp ''University of Wales, Lampeter Institutional Review Summary''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325051824/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/reviews/reports/institutional/UoWLampeter/summary.asp |date=25 March 2010 }}. Retrieved 16 June 2010. Further to this assessment, [[Higher Education Funding Council for Wales|HEFCW]] commissioned a further report which found "''very real problems of leadership and management''" at the university.Hodges, Lucy; The Independent Education (19 February 2009); [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/is-a-merger-the-only-way-to-save-lampeter-1625432.html ''Is a merger the only way to save Lampeter?: Strapped for cash and the subject of a highly critical review, Lampeter is in crisis'']. Retrieved 16 June 2010.Time Higher Education, (1 January 2009); [http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=26&storycode=404812 ''Trinity College Carmarthen – Talks start on new university'']. Retrieved 16 June 2010. As a direct result, in December 2008, Lampeter announced that it was in merger talks with Trinity with the intention of forming a new university. This was formally announced in April 2009, when the institution's new name, ''University of Wales, Trinity Saint David'', was revealed. The university received its first students in September 2010. The name of the institution is a combination of Lampeter's original name (Saint David's College) and the name of Trinity University College. In June 2010, a declaration of intent was announced between Trinity Saint David, [[Swansea Metropolitan University]] and three regional further education colleges ([[Coleg Ceredigion]], [[Pembrokeshire College|Coleg Sir Benfro]] and [[Coleg Sir Gâr]]) to establish a South-West Wales regional post-16 [[further education]] and [[higher education]] educational group.Press Releases (3 June 2010): [http://www.lamp.ac.uk/news/press_releases/2010/new-vision-to-transform-education.html ''A New Vision to Transform Education in South West Wales'']; University of Wales, Lampeter; accessed 5 July 2010 The FE colleges were to merge into one educational group, whilst the HE institutions would merge into another educational group, with both working closely within the region. In December 2010 it was announced that the university would merge with [[Swansea Metropolitan University]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-12017883 |title=Swansea Metropolitan and Trinity Saint David to merge |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 17 December 2010|accessdate=2010-12-17}} This merger was completed on 1 August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Uni-merger-goes-ahead-Met-dissolved/story-19511435-detail/story.html#axzz2ZnmhLKAE|title=Uni merger goes ahead after Met is dissolved|work=South Wales Evening Post|accessdate=31 May 2015}} In May 2011 the university announced it would be establishing the [[Wales International Academy of Voice]] in Cardiff, opening in June 2011.{{>cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606021000/http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/news/pressreleases/name,7302,en.html|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/news/pressreleases/name,7302,en.html|archive-date=6 June 2011|publisher=UWTSD|date=11 May 2011|title=The University and world leading operatic tenor Dennis O’Neill announces new Academy of Voice}} In October 2011, it was announced that the [[University of Wales]] would also be merged into Trinity Saint David.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15410424 University of Wales effectively abolished in merger] – BBC News, 21 October 2011{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15157119|title=University of Wales to stop validating other degrees|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15171830|title=University of Wales degree and visa scam exposed by BBC|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15191954|title=Scrap University of Wales call by vice-chancellors|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite news|title=Warning not to strip University of Wales assets|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15689167|accessdate=17 November 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=11 November 2011}} A deed of union signed in 2017 functionally integrated the two universities, although the full constitutional merger has not been completed as of September 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.wales.ac.uk/en/AboutUs/About-Us-2018.aspx|title=About Us|publisher=University of Wales|accessdate=12 September 2018}} A London campus was opened in 2012. In August 2012, it was announced that Coleg Sir Gâr, a further education college with five campuses across Carmarthenshire, would be merged with Trinity Saint David, forming a combined higher education and further education institution.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-23775189|title=Coleg Sir Gar merges with University of Wales: Trinity Saint David|work=BBC News|accessdate=31 May 2015}} In 2015, the university established a second centre in Cardiff with the launch of ''Canolfan Berfformio Cymru'' (the Wales Centre for Performance).{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/news/press-releases/press-releases-2014/uwtsd-celebrates-the-launch-of-canolfan-berfformio-cymru-the-wales-centre-for-performance-at-the-national-eisteddfod-.html|publisher=UWTSD|date=4 August 2015|accessdate=13 September 2018|title=UWTSD celebrates the launch of Canolfan Berfformio Cymru (The Wales Centre for Performance) at the National Eisteddfod}} In 2016, Coleg Ceredigion, another further education college with campuses in Cardigan and Aberystwyth, merged with the university.{{cite news|url=http://www.cambrian-news.co.uk/article.cfm?id=103233&headline=Cardigan%20now%20a%20university%20town%20following%20merger§ionIs=news&searchyear=2016|title=Cardigan now a university town following merger|date=30 March 2016|author=Mike Lewis|work=Cambrian News}} The university opened a "learning centre" in Birmingham in 2018, offering level 4 (first year undergraduate) courses leading to a [[Certificate of Higher Education]].{{cite web|url=www.uwtsd.ac.uk/birmingham|title=Birmingham Learning Centre|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} == Campuses == === Lampeter=== The Lampeter campus includes a number of academic, utility and residential buildings. [[File:Uwlsdb.jpg|thumb|right|St David's Building]] [[Charles Robert Cockerell]] designed the original college building, now called the Saint David's Building (informally known as Old Building or OB by students) in the centre of the grounds. It is a Grade II* [[listed building]] and contains lecture rooms, administrative offices, student residential accommodation and the following three main areas: The Old Hall was the college dining hall until the Lloyd Thomas refectory was opened in 1969. It then became part of the students' union, used as a venue for meetings and dances. After the opening of a new students' union building, it fell into disuse until 1991 when it was re-opened after much restoration; it is now used as one of the university's principal venues for meetings, dinners and conferences and is often hired out to outside organisations. It is also used for examinations and occasional lectures. The Old Hall also contains paintings of various principals, presidents, benefactors, vice-chancellors ''et al.'' including the founder of the University Bishop [[Thomas Burgess (bishop)|Thomas Burgess]], [[Maurice Jones]], [[Thomas Price (Carnhuanawc)|Thomas Price]], [[Llewelyn Lewellin]], [[Edward Harold Browne]], [[Keith Robbins]] and [[Brian Morris, Baron Morris of Castle Morris|Brian Robert Morris]]. St David's Chapel was consecrated in 1827. In 1879, it was rebuilt according to the specifications of the architect [[Thomas Graham Jackson]] of Cambridge and re-opened on 24 June 1880. It was again refurbished during the 1930s, mainly through the provision of a new [[reredos]] (incorporating depictions of St David, Christ and [[St Deiniol]] in 1933 and a major overhaul of the organ in 1934. The chapel is provided with a dedicated chaplain and services are held here on Sundays and throughout the week as well as on saints' days and major festivals. These are generally well-attended by a mixture of staff, students and alumni. [[File:Cantuwl.jpg|thumb|left|The original Canterbury Building (1887–1971)]] The Founders' Library, named after its founders — [[Thomas Burgess (bishop)|Thomas Burgess]], [[Thomas Bowdler]] and [[Thomas Phillips (educational benefactor)|Thomas Phillips]] — was the College's library until the new library opened in 1966 and later housed the priceless collection of the university's oldest printed books (1470–1850) and manuscripts (the earliest being from the 13th century) unique to the university, given to St David's College from 1822 onwards, as well as the university's archives. In 2005, it was announced that a new £700,000 extension, The Roderic Bowen Library & Archives, was to be built adjoining the Main Library to house the university's manuscripts, as the Founders' Library was not environmentally suitable for such valuable documents. This extension to the main library was completed and opened in 2008. The former Founders' Library was subsequently refurbished and was reopened by HRH [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] to provide outside conference and seminar facilities. ==== Later additions ==== [[File:Cantuwl2.JPG|thumb|The second Canterbury Building (1973–2012).]] ''The Canterbury Building'' was built to house a growing number of students at the end of the 19th century. The foundation stone was laid by the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] in 1885 and the building was officially opened on 24 June 1887. It contained a physical science laboratory, two lecture rooms and new accommodation. However, structural problems forced the university to demolish the original building in the summer of 1971. The second Canterbury Building was opened on 20 October 1973 by the Vice-Chancellor of the [[University of Kent]] and at various times housed the History, Classics, Foundation, Welsh and English departments. The second Canterbury Building was demolished during 2012, and the third Canterbury Building, opened during the 2012/13 academic year, now houses the Student Services Hub.http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/theuniversity/investing9millionpoundsinyouruniversity/developmentsonthelampetercampus/ "Developments on the Lampeter Campus" [[File:Uni Library Lampeter.JPG|thumb|left|The Learning Resources Centre/Main Library entrance.]] ''The Library'' was opened on 7 July 1966 by the then Chancellor of the University of Wales, HRH [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]]. It was extended and then reopened by HRH [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] on 21 June 1984. ''The Arts Building'' was built to house the geography department and was opened by The Rt. Hon [[Peter Thomas, Baron Thomas of Gwydir|Peter Thomas]], [[Secretary of State for Wales]] on 4 October 1971. Currently, the Arts Building houses the School of Archaeology, History and Anthropology and the School of Management, VSS, IT, Business and Tourism as well as the Department of Philosophy. [[File:Cliff Tucker Building.JPG|thumb|The Cliff Tucker Building]] ''The Cliff Tucker building'', on the banks of the [[River Dulas]], was opened by Sir [[Anthony Hopkins]] in 1996 on the site of the former archaeology practice trenches and incorporates several teaching rooms and a lecture theatre. It is named in honour of [[Cliff Tucker]], a former student and benefactor of the university. [[File:Sheikh Khalifa Building.JPG|thumb|left|The Sheikh Khalifa building, in the town opposite the campus.]] Completed in 1997 and named after Sheikh [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], a benefactor of the UWL, the ''Sheikh Khalifa building'' is the home of the School of Theology, Religious Studies and Islamic Studies, one of the largest Schools of its kind in the United Kingdom. It was opened by Professor Sir [[Stewart Sutherland, Baron Sutherland of Houndwood|Stewart Sutherland]]. Behind the departmental building is a small [[mosque]] and prayer room, used by Islamic students and residents of the town, and also the Rowland Williams Research building. Opened in 2007, the ''Confucius Institute'' is the home of the university's department of Chinese Studies. The mission of the Confucius Institute has been to build bridges between Wales and China. ''The Roderic Bowen Library & Archives'' were completed in 2007, adjoining the main library building. They are named after [[Roderic Bowen]], a former President of the university. The books, manuscripts and archives kept therein were formerly held in the St David's Building Founders’ Library. The library was opened on 17 October 2008 by the former [[First Minister for Wales]], [[Rhodri Morgan]]. It is a resource for teaching, research and scholarship within the university. ''The Students' Union'' houses the university's main entertainment venue, the Xtension, a bar, television and pool rooms, student shop and offices for union officials. It is the main focus of social life on campus, hosting club nights, socials, pool tournaments and charity events. ''The Bishop Burgess Hall'' formerly housed the Departments of Classics and Philosophy. In 2009 it was converted to become a hub for student services. === Gallery === Image:St David building inside.JPG|Inside the cloisters of Saint David's Building. Image:Roderic Bowen Library.JPG|The Roderick Bowen Library & Archives extension to the Main Library. Image:Arts Building Lampeter.JPG|The Arts Building entrance, before refurbishment in 2013. Image:The Xtension Bar.JPG|The Xtension Bar which contains the campus's [[nightclub]]. Image:Students Union Lampeter.JPG|The Students' Union building (Ty Ceredig) containing the Old Bar === Carmarthen === [[File:Trinity College, Carmarthen Wales.jpg|thumb|right|Old College, Carmarthen]] Although its foundation and indeed its speciality lies in education, the campus now also teaches a variety of degrees in subjects such as sport, health and nutrition, religious and Islamic studies, psychology, social inclusion, creative arts, photography, film and drama, business and tourism, and English and creative writing. The Carmarthen campus is the base of two of the university's three faculties. {{cite web|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/location/carmarthencampus/|title=Carmarthen Campus|author=Web Development Team – UWTSD|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015}} The campus is centred around the original 1848 ''Old Building'' of Trinity College. It originally contained all of the original dormitories, common rooms, libraries, an original university quadrangle and teaching spaces. The building today houses several lecture theatres and smaller classrooms often used by the university's School of Justice and Social Inclusion (including psychology) and theology, religious studies and Islamic studies. [[File:Picture of Old Building Carmarthen.jpg|thumb|Old Building Carmarthen]] Another feature of the old building of Carmarthen is the ''Archbishop Childs' Hall''. Named after [[Derrick Greenslade Childs]], who was [[Archbishop of Wales]], [[Bishop of Monmouth]] and director of the Church of Wales. Childs was principal of Trinity in 1965. The hall is of a classical shape and is hung with framed paintings of Childs. On the outside of the building, there is a carved crest of the Bishops of Wales. ''Cwad'' – The original 1848 quadrangle, what later became the old college library has been modified into the 'Cwad'. This operates in partnership with the main library. [[File:Chapel at Trinity University College Carmarthen.JPG|thumb|Chapel building exterior]] Attached to the main body of the Old Building is the ''University Chapel''. This was built in 1848 and although it has been modified slightly, still retains many original features. Attached to this is the historic ante-chapel, the original chapel the present one being an extension added in 1932, which is dedicated to past students and professors who served in the first world war. The ante-chapel contains a font and is decorated with student artwork. There is also the university chapel lounge which now houses the university's chaplaincy library and serves as a comfortable, relaxed meeting space for the Chapel community. This room also has a stained glass window installed in 2008 in memory of [[Norah Isaac]], former lecturer and pioneer of Welsh language education. ==== Later additions ==== The surrounding campus is a blend of modern buildings surrounded by sweeping lawns and gardens. Opposite the old building is the ''Halliwell Centre'', named after a former principal of Trinity College, which is primarily used as a conference facility. Attached to the centre is the Merlin restaurant which is the campus' main restaurant and refectory for catered students.{{cite web|url=http://www.tsd.ac.uk/en/halliwell/aboutthehalliwell/|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David – Error 404: Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015}} [[File:Halliwell Building, Trinity University College Carmarthen.jpg|thumb|left|Halliwell Building, Carmarthen]] ''The Carwyn James Building'' is a large four-storey building named after [[Carwyn James]], a former Welsh rugby player, teacher and lecturer at Trinity College. This facility is home to the Faculty of Education and Training. ''Emyr Wyn Jones Building''- This building contains office space, music suites and practice rooms for the School of Performing Arts. Adjoining this building was the School's main workshop for the degree of theatre production and design. ''The Dewi Building'' was originally built in 1925 as the Dewi Hostel. It was an extension of the original old college and served as an extra wing for student accommodation. An account of the conditions of the hostel survives from a student living in them at the time; ''“To keep oneself warm in the new wing during the Winter months was a problem for although it had a system of heating, the heat seldom reached even the second floor. To wash we depended on the rain-water caught in the roof of the building and this was always cold”.''{{cite web|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/alumni/trinitycollegealumni/history/|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David – Error 404: Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015}} ''The main library'' of the university campus was constructed in 1995 to accommodate the growing diversity of subjects on the campus and is located opposite the Parry Block. It is dedicated to the poet [[Raymond Garlick]], who was a principal lecturer in Trinity's Welsh department. ''The Parry Building'', named after [[Canon Parry]] (a former principal of the college and psychology lecturer 1909–1940),{{cite web|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/alumni/trinitycollegealumni/history/yourmemories/mrgeorgeheadmbe/|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David – Error 404: Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502032529/http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/alumni/trinitycollegealumni/history/yourmemories/mrgeorgeheadmbe/|archive-date=2 May 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} contains a variety of teaching facilities used largely by the university's School of Creative Arts. These include fairly large classrooms and smaller art studios. The building runs parallel to the Norah Isaac building and the two are of very similar designs. Originally the front façade of the building, the oldest part, was the broadcast room in 1950. ''Students' Union'' – The students' union building was the centre of student social life on the campus. Constructed in 1972 it comprised two main venues: the Attic Bar which served food and drinks and downstairs 'Unity', the main entertainment venue of the Union. This facility hosted club nights as well as other social events. The Union incorporated many societies, ranging from sports such as rugby and hockey to historical societies. ''Norah Isaac Building'' – This building is home to the school of social justice and Inclusion and contains the reception for that school. It is named after [[Norah Isaac]], who was responsible for setting up the first ever Welsh drama department, and was a founder of the performing arts tradition at Trinity.{{cite web|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/news/newsarchives/trinityuniversitycollege/name,984,en.html|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David – Error 404: Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015}} It has a selection of classrooms and lecture suites. Degrees in English and Creative Writing are also taught in this building, which is also home to the university's foreign office, which deals with international programmes. It is located directly opposite the Parry Building. ''Robert Hunter Building'' – Named after Robert Hunter, this building contains a selection of classrooms, lecture halls and laboratories used by the school of sport, health and outdoor education. The facility is located near the Myrddin Accommodation blocks, and is surrounded by picturesque gardens and ponds. ''Dafydd Rowlands Building'' – Named after the author [[Dafydd Rowlands]], a minister and previous lecturer of Trinity College in the Welsh department, the building is home to the university's department of Film and Visual Media, this space contains laboratories and studios as well as several working spaces for other programmes within the school of creative arts. It also houses office space. === Swansea === [[File:Alexandra Road campus c. 1890s.jpg|thumb|Alexandra Road campus (1890s)]] [[File:Swansea Met Mount Pleasant.JPG|thumb|right|Part of Swansea 's Mount Pleasant Campus]] UWTSD took over the campuses of [[Swansea Metropolitan University]] upon the merger of the two institutions. These now make up part of the Swansea city centre campuses of the university, consisting of the Dynevor campus, the [[Mount Pleasant, Swansea|Mount Pleasant]] campus, the Alex Design Exchange, and the Swansea Business Campus.{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/swansea/|title=Swansea Campuses|publisher= UWTSD|accessdate=14 September 2018}} In 2018 the university is opening a new £350 million campus at the [[SA1 Swansea Waterfront]], which will house Yr Athrofa: the Institute of Education, and the Faculty of Architecture, Computing and Engineering.{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/sa1/|title=SA1 Swansea Waterfront|publisher= UWTSD|accessdate=14 September 2018}} Staff and students from the city centre Townhill and Mount Pleasant campuses are relocating to SA1, with Townhill closing at the end of the 2017-18 academic year although the university is retaining a presence at Mount Pleasant.{{cite news|url=https://wales247.co.uk/university-begins-move-to-350-million-sa1-swansea-waterfront-development/|title=University begins move to £350 million SA1 Swansea Waterfront development|date=20 June 2018|work= Wales 247|author=Rhys Gregory}} === London=== The university's London Campus opened in 2012 and is located in Winchester House on [[Cranmer Road]] in the [[London Borough of Lambeth]]. The campus hosts [[MBA]] programmes run by the university’s School of Business, many of which courses are aimed at attracting overseas students.http://www.tsdlondon.ac.uk/en/media/tsdlondon/content/documents/mba_prospectus_2012_13.pdf ==Partners== The university is a part of what has been called a dual-sector university, delivering both higher and further education. It has partnerships with a number of other further and higher education institutions across the UK, including:{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/collaborative-partnerships/register-of-collaborative-partnerships/|title=Register of Collaborative Partnerships|accessdate=13 September 2018|publisher=UWTSD}} * [[Coleg Sir Gâr]] (constituent college) * [[Coleg Ceredigion]] (constituent college) * Glasgow Academy Musical Theatre Arts * [[Gower College Swansea]] * [[Hereford College of Arts]] * [[London School of Commerce]] (associate college) * [[NPTC Group]] * [[Newbold College|Newbold College of Higher Education]] * [[Pembrokeshire College]] * [[Schumacher College]] * St Padarn's Institute * [[The Prince's Foundation for Building Community]] * [[The Prince's School of Traditional Arts]] It also has a number of international validation and franchise agteements, as well as [[Articulation (education)|articulation]] agreements with [[Renmin University of China]] and [[Wuhan University of Technology]], China. ==Organisation and governance== === Faculties === The university is organised into a number of academic schools and faculties.{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/schools-faculties/|title=Academic Schools and Faculties|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} {{Div col}} *Faculty of Architecture, Computing and Engineering{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/face/|title=Faculty of Architecture, Computing and Engineering|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} (Swansea) **School of Applied Computing **School of Architecture, Built and Natural Environments **School of Engineering *Swansea College of Art *Faculty of Business and Management{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/business-management/|title=Faculty of Business and Management|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} ** Swansea Business School ** Carmarthen Business School ** Swansea School of Tourism and Hospitality ** Wales Institute for Workplace Learning * Yr Athrofa: Institute of Education{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/athrofa/|title=Yr Athrofa: Institute of Education|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} (Swansea) ** School of Early Years ** School of Psychology ** School of Social Justice and Inclusion ** South West Wales Centre of Teacher Education ** Centre for Continuing Professional Learning and Development * Faculty of Humanities and Performing Arts{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/humanities-performingarts/|title=Humanities and Performing Arts at UWTSD|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} ** Humanities (Lampeter) ** Film, Media and Performing Arts (Carmarthen) ** Wales International Academy of Voice (Cardiff) ** Canolfan Berffomio Cymru (Cardiff) ** Confucius Institute ** Academy of Sinology * London Campus === Vice-Chancellor === {{main article|List of Vice-Chancellors of the University of Wales, Trinity Saint David}} The Vice-Chancellor is the chief executive of the university and the post is currently held by [[Medwin Hughes]]. ==Academic profile== ===Reputation=== {{Infobox UK university rankings | ARWU_N = | ARWU_W = | QS_N = | QS_W = | THE_N = | THE_W = | LINE_1 = 0 | Complete = 115 | The_Guardian = 85 | Times/Sunday_Times = 104 | LINE_2 = 0 | TEF = Bronze }} The university was the first in the UK to place at its core sustainable development. The university's Institute of Sustainable Practice and Resource Effectiveness or INSPIRE is designed to ensure that students are prepared for their futures in the workplace and in society as a whole.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/may/10/universityguide-uni-wales-lampeter | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801181810/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/may/10/universityguide-uni-wales-lampeter|archive-date=1 August 2013|location=London | work=The Guardian | title=University guide 2013: University of Wales, Trinity St David | date=28 May 2012}} ===Entry requirements=== With many of the degrees offered by the university there is less emphasis placed upon [[UCAS points]] and more upon individual merit especially regarding [[mature student]]s. However, for many of the degrees offered within the Faculty of Humanities a set number of UCAS points is required; for most courses this is usually between 240–280. For postgraduate taught programs a minimum of an upper second class degree is required.{{cite web|url=http://www.trinitysaintdavid.ac.uk/en/postgraduate/howtoapply/|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David – Error 404: Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2015}} === Research === The university has continued the tradition of research in the humanities at Lampeter.{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/research/humanities-lampeter/|title=Humanities in Lampeter Research|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} In the 2014 [[Research Excellence Framework]] (REF2014), 47% of the university's research was judged as world leading (4*) or internationally excellent (3*).{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/news/press-releases/press-releases-2014/uwtsd-celebrates-ref-results.html|title=UWTSD Celebrates REF Results|date=18 December 2014|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} The university entered six units of assessment in REF2014, with 26% of research being judged 4* and 39% 3* in Modern Languages and Linguistics (jointly with the University of Wales's Centre for Advanced Celtic Studies), 23% 4* and 52% 3* in Art and Design: History Practice and Theory (jointly with the University of South Wales and Cardiff Metropolitan University as the Wales Institute for Research in Art and Design), 14% 4* and 48% 3* in Theology and Religious Studies, 9% 4* and 25% 3* in Geography, Environmental Studies and Archaeology, 4% 4* and 38% 3* in Classics, and 3% 3* in General Engineering.{{cite web|url=http://results.ref.ac.uk/Results/ByHei/185|title=University of Wales Trinity Saint David|publisher=REF2014|accessdate=13 September 2018}} The pioneering Sophia Centre for the Study of Cosmology in Culture is a world centre for the study of the impact, role and function of cosmological, astronomical and astrological beliefs and practices in human culture.{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/research/humanities-lampeter/sophia-centre/|title=Sophia Centre|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} == Student life == ===Students' union=== [[File:TSDSULogo.png|thumb|Logo of the Trinity Saint David Students' Union]] Students are represented by Trinity Saint David Students' Union ('''TSDSU''').{{cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/students-union/|title=Students' Union|publisher=UWTSD|accessdate=13 September 2018}} The students union has buildings on all three main campuses, with bars in Carmarthen (Taphouse72) and Lampeter (Old Bar & Xtention).{{cite web|url=https://www.tsdsu.co.uk/shop|title=Eat, Drink and Shop|publisher=TSDSU|accessdate=13 September 2018}} === Sports === Both Lampeter and Carmarthen campuses have sports halls with [[badminton]] and [[Squash (sport)|squash]] courts, with a hockey team drawing from students of both campuses and a fencing team based on the St David's College campus which regularly competes in Welsh leagues and championships. Both campuses also have indoor climbing walls. For outdoor sports, the university has [[tennis court]]s, a [[cricket]] field and facilities for football and rugby. The Carmarthen Campus also has an indoor swimming pool, an up-to-date gym and fitness suite and AstroTurf. There plans in motion to add gym facilities to Lampeter through the conversion of one of the squash courts. The college cricket pavilion at Lampeter was opened officially on 1 May 1909 and is now a [[listed building]] in its own right.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} ==== Rugby ==== Rugby was introduced to the old St David's College by vice-principal [[Rowland Williams (theologian)|Rowland Williams]] around 1850 and, as such, the Lampeter campus can claim to have the oldest [[Rugby football]] team in Wales. Despite some debate as to whether this honour belongs to the town team or the university side, the Welsh Rugby Union's official history "Fields of Praise: The Official History of the Welsh Rugby Union, 1881–1981"Fields of Praise, The Official History of the Welsh Rugby Union 1881–1981 pp259, David Smith, Gareth Williams (1980) indicates the college team as the first. However, [[Lampeter Town RFC]] were the representatives of Lampeter at the formation of the WRU in 1881.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} At Trinity, Rugby has long been an important part of college life. Indeed, a number of alumni went on to become outstanding international players including [[Sid Judd]], [[Ronnie Boon]], [[Dewi Bebb]] and [[Barry John]]. Wales and British Lions winger, [[Gerald Davies]], is a former student of both former universities.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} === Halls of residence === Both Carmarthen and Lampeter campuses provide on-campus halls of residence, although some students opt to live in privately rented student housing within the respective towns. Both campuses can house approximately 600 students. ==== Lampeter Campus ==== The university provides various residences for students. The Lampeter Campus is generally able to house the majority of its students on campus principally within the following Halls and Buildings, named after personalities involved with the campus's past. *Carl Lofmark Hall *Cyfle Hall *Bishop Burgess Hall (originally ordinands-only) *Daniel Dawson Hall *Dolwen Cottage *[[Alfred Edwin Morris|Edwin Morris]] Hall *Garth House *[[John Scandrett Harford|Harford]] Building I & II (originally female-only)Russell-Jones, Ruth (2007); ''A History of the Lampeter Society 1937–2007''; Lampeter: University of Wales, Lampeter; pp. 21–22 *[[Harold Arthur Harris]] Hall *[[Hugh Walker (academic)|Hugh Walker]] Hall *John Richards Hall I & II *[[John Roland Lloyd Thomas|Lloyd Thomas]] Hall I, II & III *Rhoslwyn Hall *Riverside Cottage *[[Roderic Bowen]] Hall *Simon Evans Hall *St David’s Building/Old Building (originally male-only) ==== Carmarthen Campus ==== The Carmarthen Campus is able to house hundreds of students on Campus, though many students opt to live in the town. [[File:Arch Bishop Noakes Student accommodation.jpg|thumb|Arch Bishop Noakes Student accommodation]] *[[George Noakes|Archbishop Noakes]] Hall: this is a large accommodation facility that is split into three sections. *[[Merlin|Myrddin]] Hall: this is a catered first year hall, built in the 1970s to accommodate the rise in student numbers. *[[Saint Non|Non]] Hall: originally built in 1957 opposite the old Dewi Hostel to accommodate the first female students. *Tower Hall: this too is a catered first-year block. ==== Swansea Campus ==== Swansea has five halls of residence based on two separate campuses. There are over 300 rooms for first year students to apply for. ==== Townhill Campus ==== *Gwyr Hall *Dyfed Hall *Cenydd Hall ==== Mount Pleasant Campus ==== {{empty section|date=January 2014}} == Academic dress == {{Update|inaccurate=yes|section|date=October 2011}} {{Main article|Academic dress of the University of Wales}} The university awards University of Wales degrees and, as such, the academic dress matches that of the University of Wales — graduates wear a black stuff gown, with bell sleeves for [[Bachelor of Arts|bachelors]] and glove sleeve for [[Master of Arts|masters]]. Hoods are lined with mazarin blue shot green (arts) or mazarin blue shot red (divinity). The university also awards the degrees of [[Master of Science]] (lined yellow shot black) and [[Master of Business Administration]] (yellow shot red, bound light blue). ==Notable alumni== *[[Dewi Bebb]], Welsh International Rugby Player (Carmarthen, Education) *[[Jonathan Clements]], Author (Swansea, PhD Applied Design and Engineering)Clements, ''Anime: A History'' London: British Film Institute, 2013. p.v. *[[Carl Cooper]], [[Bishop of St David's]] (Lampeter, French) *[[Juliette Foster]], Journalist (Lampeter, History with Church History) *[[Barry John]], Welsh International Rugby Player (Carmarthen, Education) *[[John C. Knapp]], President, [[Hope College]], United States (Lampeter, Theology) *[[Peter Paphides]], Music Journalist (Lampeter, Philosophy) *[[H. Jefferson Powell]], Former Principal Deputy [[Solicitor General]] of the United States (Lampeter, Theology) *[[Rebecca Wheatley]], '[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]' Actress (Lampeter, English Literature) *[[Ramzi Ahmed Yousef]], perpetrator of [[1993 World Trade Center bombing]] (Swansea, electrical engineering) * Prof David Kitchener, Professor of Inclusion and Diversity, University of Bolton. (Carmarthen, Education) == See also == *[[University of Wales]] *[[List of universities in Wales]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *Gibson, William (2007); ''In a Class by Itself''; Lampeter: Lampeter Society *Groves, Nicholas (2001); ''Academical Robes of Saint David's College Lampeter (1822–1871)''; University of Wales, Lampeter Special Publications ({{ISBN|0-905285-68-9}}). *Price, D T W; ''A History of Saint David's University College, Lampeter''; Cardiff: University of Wales Press. Volume One, to 1898 ({{ISBN|0-7083-0606-3}}) Volume Two 1898–1971 ({{ISBN|0-7083-1062-1}}). *Price, D T W; ''Yr Esgob Burgess a Choleg Llanbedr: Bishop Burgess and Lampeter College''; Cardiff: University of Wales Press ({{ISBN|0-7083-0965-8}}) *Russell-Jones, Ruth (2007); ''A History of the Lampeter Society: 1937–2007''; Lampeter: Lampeter Society ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{official website|http://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/}} * [https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/students-union/ Student's Union website] {{University of Wales}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{Universities and colleges in Wales}} {{Universities in the United Kingdom}} {{Ceredigion}} {{Carmarthenshire}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:University Of Wales Trinity Saint David}} [[Category:University of Wales]] [[Category:Education in Ceredigion]] [[Category:Education in Carmarthenshire]] [[Category:University of Wales, Trinity Saint David|*]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2010]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Wales]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=see [[WP:MOSFLAG]]|date=November 2014}} {{update|date=April 2014}} }}
The '''[[Webometrics]] Ranking of World Universities''', also known as '''Ranking Web of Universities''', is a ranking system for the world's universities based on a composite indicator that takes into account both the volume of the Web contents (number of web pages and files) and the visibility and impact of these web publications according to the number of external inlinks (site citations) they received. The ranking is published by the [[Cybermetrics Lab]], a research group of the [[Spanish National Research Council]] (CSIC) located in Madrid.
The aim of the Ranking is to improve the presence of the [[academic]] and research [[institution]]s on the Web and to promote the [[open access (publishing)|open access]] publication of scientific results.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/53631/in-the-know-webometrics-ranking-of-world-universities | title=In The Know: Webometrics Ranking of World Universities |publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=6 September 2011 |accessdate=January 19, 2012}}</ref> The ranking started in 2004 and is updated every January and July. Today it provides Web indicators for more than 12,000 [[university|universities]] worldwide.
The '''[[Webometrics Ranking of Business Schools]]''' is a similar ranking of the world's Business Schools.
==Objectives== The Webometrics University Ranking is a ranking system based on university web presence, visibility and web access.<ref name="bappi2">{{cite web |url=http://www.webometrics.info/en |title= Webometrics ranking |work=webometrics.info |accessdate=18 January 2015}}</ref> This ranking system measures how strongly a university is present in the web by its own web domain, sub-pages, rich files, scholarly articles etc.<ref name="bappi2"/> The central hypothesis of this approach is that web presence is a reliable indicator of the global performance and prestige of the universities and as such, is an indirect way to measure all the university missions (teaching, research, transfer). Although the Web is universally recognized as one of the most relevant tools for scholarly communication, it is still very rare these indicators are used for the evaluation of the scientific research and the academic performance of universities. Webometric indicators are provided to show the commitment of the institutions to Web publication.
A research paper in the peer-reviewed scientific journal ''Scientometrics'' found "reasonable similarities" between the Webometrics rankings and other prominent university rankings despite using a very different set of features to determine each university's rank. These similarities were increased when the comparison was limited solely to European universities.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.akademiai.com/content/k7403201200nv504/ |title=Comparing university rankings |publisher=Akadémiai Kiadó, co-published with Springer Science+Business Media B.V., Formerly Kluwer Academic Publishers B.V. |work=Scientometrics |date=February 23, 2010 |accessdate=January 19, 2012 |author=Aguillo|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Top universities are publishing millions of pages produced by dozens of departments and services, hundreds of research teams and thousands of scholars. Strong [[web presence]] informs of a wide variety of factors that are clearly correlated with the global quality of the institution: widespread availability of computer resources available, global internet literacy, policies promoting democracy and freedom of speech, competition for international visibility or support of open access initiatives, among others.
==Impact== In [[Namibia]], the Webometrics list is frequently used in public interaction, particularly with respect to the country's two main state-funded institutions of tertiary education, the [[University of Namibia]] and the [[Polytechnic of Namibia]].<ref name="Kiremire1">{{cite news|author=Enos Kiremire|title=African University Ranking Sub-Saharan Africa: (July 2009: University of Namibia)|newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]]|url=http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=6323|date=21 August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316095301/http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=6323|archivedate=16 March 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name="Kiremire2">{{cite news|author=Enos Kiremire|title=Unam could move to top 10|newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]]|url=http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=9932|date=12 March 2010|access-date=2010-11-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316095526/http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=9932#|archive-date=2012-03-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The 2009-2011 rankings have received significant press coverage and individual rankings have been published on the websites of universities in countries in the [[Middle East]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://enews.ksu.edu.sa/en/node/102145 |title=Webometrics' Ranking Reflects King Saud University's Significant International Presence |publisher=King Saud University |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119013350/http://enews.ksu.edu.sa/en/node/102145 |archivedate=19 January 2015 |df= }}</ref> [[East Asia]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asianscientist.com/2011/08/academia/webometrics-web-ranking-2011-national-taiwan-university-top-asia/ |title=Webometrics Web Ranking 2011: National Taiwan University Top In Asia |publisher=Asian Scientist |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news-en.secr.ncku.edu.tw/files/14-1083-75363,r614-1.php |title=NCKU Ranks 80th in Webometrics Ranking of World Universities |publisher=National Cheung Kung University |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728160132/http://news-en.secr.ncku.edu.tw/files/14-1083-75363,r614-1.php# |archive-date=2013-07-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[European Union|Europe]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pw.edu.pl/engpw/News/The-Warsaw-University-of-Technology-in-Webometrics-Ranking-of-World-Universities|title=The Warsaw University of Technology in "Webometrics Ranking of World Universities"|last=Technology|first=Warsaw University of|work=Warsaw University of Technology|access-date=2018-03-22|language=pl}}</ref> [[Canada]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nouvelles.umontreal.ca/udem-news/news/universite-de-montreal-among-webometrics-ranking-of-world-universities.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609011000/http://www.nouvelles.umontreal.ca/udem-news/news/universite-de-montreal-among-webometrics-ranking-of-world-universities.html |archivedate=9 June 2011 |title=Université de Montréal among Webometrics Ranking of World Universities |publisher=Universite de Montreal |date=17 February 2009 | accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref> and [[Africa]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shout-africa.com/top-story/liberian-universities-appearance-in-webometrics-ranking-of-world%E2%80%99s-universities/ |title=Liberian Universities appearance in Webometrics ranking of World's Universities | publisher=Shout Africa | date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2012 |author=Peterking Quaye}}</ref>
==Structure and contents== There are pages for several regional Rankings:
- '''Universities.''' The main worldwide list of 12000 universities build from a catalogue of over 19000 institutions is also offered as regional lists: *USA & Canada *Europe, including Turkey, Caucasus & Israel **Central & Eastern Europe *Asia, excluding Middle East **South East Asia **South Asia, Indian Subcontinent *Arab & Persian World (North Africa & Middle East) *Africa *Latin America: Central, South America & Caribbean *Oceania
The distribution of the Universities by region (January 2012) is as follows:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Region ! Top 100 ! Top 200 ! Top 500 ! Top 1000 ! Total |- | North America | 79 | 99 | 178 | 398 | 3485 |- | Europe | 16 | 66 | 212 | 415 | 4975 |- | Asia | 3 | 20 | 66 | 104 | 6142 |- | Latin America | 2 | 9 | 19 | 39 | 3487 |- | Oceania | 1 | 6 | 20 | 35 | 149 |- | Arab World | 0 | 0 | 2 | 4 | 569 |- | Africa | 0 | 0 | 3 | 5 | 355 |- | World | | | | | 19161 |}
- '''Research Institutes'''. Top 2000 from a catalogue of over 7000 are published
==Authorship== The Webometrics Ranking is produced by the [[Cybermetrics Lab]], a unit of the [[Spanish National Research Council]] (CSIC), the main public research body in Spain. The Lab acts as an Observatory of the Science and Technology on the Web. Isidro F. Aguillo, [[Honorary degree|Hon.PhD]], is the head of the Laboratory and the editor-in-chief of the Rankings.
==Notes and references== * ''Rankings by [http://www.webometrics.info/ Webometrics] in this article are licensed [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/ CC-BY 2.5] which permits reuse under the [[Wikipedia:Text of Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License|Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License]]. All relevant terms must be followed.''
{{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.webometrics.info/}}
{{University ranking systems}} {{Portal bar|University}}
[[Category:University and college rankings]]

{{Infobox University |name = West Coast University |native_name = West Coast Institute of Management & Technology |image_name = West Coast University – Panama logo.jpg |image_size = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 1996 |closed = |type = Autonomous Educational Institution |affiliation = |endowment = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = |president = Prof. Dr. S. Lloyd |vice-president = Dr. M. Kafafy |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = Prof. Dr.Carlos Gustavo Lavado Roqué |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = Registrar |head = Quinn Lloyd |faculty = |staff = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Panama City]] |state = |province = |country = [[Panama]] |coor = |campus = |former_names = West Coast Institute of Management & Technology(WCIMT) |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = |colours = |nickname = |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = |website = [http://www.westcoastuniversity.edu.pa www.westcoastuniversity.edu.pa] |logo = |footnotes = }} '''West Coast University of Panama''' is a higher education provider based in [[Panama]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newagebd.com/2007/apr/17/met.html#2 |title=UGC asked to sue West Coast University – Panama | newspaper=The Daily Newspaper |location=Dhaka |date=April 17, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205124055/http://www.newagebd.com/2007/apr/17/met.html |archivedate=5 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osac.state.or.us/oda/unaccredited.aspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525082240/http://www.osac.state.or.us/oda/unaccredited.aspx |title=Unaccredited colleges |publisher =[[Oregon Office of Degree Authorization]] |archivedate=May 25, 2011 |quote=This name ''[West Coast University]'' is used by multiple unaccredited entities. The extent to which they are related is unknown. All outside the U.S. are considered degree mills because they lack appropriate governmental authority to issue degrees. }}</ref>
==History == The "West Coast Institute of Management & Technology (WCIMT)" was established in 1996 at [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] by a [[Christian]] family "S. Lloyd Family Trust" to provide vocational and Professional Educational Services at National and International Levels under a Christian mission and vision of preaching, teaching and Social work. It is an Autonomous Educational Institute and Vocational Training School.
The institute was a registered and accredited training institution, accredited by the [[Training Accreditation Council]] (TAC) of the [[Training Department of the Government of Western Australia]], and is listed on the "[[Commonwealth]] Register of Institutions and Courses" (CRICOS), which provide accredited courses to local and overseas students up to Graduate Diploma Level.
WCIMT established a chain of affiliated colleges in many countries. In 2004, the trustees decided to use this infrastructure to establish the West Coast University in a favorable country; on the recommendations of faculty members West Coast University was incorporated at [[Panama City]], under article 19 of law 32 of 1927. The word "West Coast" does have an historical background in Panama. West Coast University, although based in Panama, serves as a global institute for autonomous higher education.
In March 2007 a [[Bangladesh]] online newspaper reported that the nation's education ministry and University Grants Commission had found that West Coast University was operating illegally in Bangladesh and the education ministry was seeking to [[lawsuit|sue]] the institution for offering bachelor's degree courses without government authorization. Government personnel said that in 2006 West Coast had opened a campus in [[Khulna]], where in February 2007 the school began conducting courses in electrical and electronic engineering, civil engineering, mechanical engineering and architecture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newagebd.com/2007/apr/17/met.html#2 |title=UGC asked to sue West Coast University – Panama | newspaper=The Daily Newspaper |location=Dhaka |date=April 17, 2007 |author=Siddiqur Rahman Khan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205124055/http://www.newagebd.com/2007/apr/17/met.html |archivedate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
In July 2012, an English-language online newspaper for Panama reported that West Coast University was advertising courses to be conducted there, but Panama's National Council of University Assessment and Accreditation (CONEAUPA) and Ministry of Education said the institution was not accredited and they had no record of the institution being legally established or having approved curricula.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20120709094530352 |title=West Coast University of Panama Called Into Question |date=July 9, 2012 |author=Don Winner |work=Panama Guide |accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref>
As of December 2012, West Coast University is a candidate for [[higher education accreditation|accreditation]] from the [[Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs]], for its bachelor's and graduate programs in business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid=14|title=Current ACBSP Accredited Programs and Members|publisher=Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001185513/http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid%3D14|archivedate=2012-10-01|df=}}</ref>
As of January 2013 West Coast University is now accredited by the International Accreditation Organization (IAO). The IAO is not recognised by the [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]] or the Council for Higher Education Accreditation.<ref>{{cite book|title=Distributed Learning and Virtual Librarianship|year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59158-906-8|page=284|author=Arne J Almquist|editor=Sharon G. Almquist|chapter=Academic Libraries, Marketing, Accreditation, and Support}}</ref><ref name=geteducatedfake>{{citation |url=http://www.geteducated.com/diploma-mills-police/college-degree-mills/204-fake-agencies-for-college-accreditation |title=Unrecognized and Fake Agencies for Online College Accreditation |publisher=GetEducated.com |accessdate=January 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url =http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/10/19/questions-about-faculty-list-new-university| title=Startup University's Phantom Faculty |date=October 19, 2012 |author=Paul Fain | work=[[Inside HigherEd]] |quote=International Accreditation Organization (IAO), [is] a self-described "secondary" accrediting body that seeks to "recognize and accredit education providers on an international scale," according to its website. The Texas-based accreditor said its seal of approval is not to be claimed as a primary accreditation, which is how Cambridge Graduate is using it. [[George Gollin|[George] Gollin]] questioned relying on the accreditor in any capacity. He cited bogus degree providers on IAO’s list of accredited institutions, including one with ties to a known degree mill operator. ... Gollin notes that one of IAO’s fully accredited institutions is the University of Antarctica (motto: "Big Continent, Big Opportunities"), which the accreditor recently removed from its website. ... Accrediting the University of Antarctica should be a "one-strike-you’re-out disqualification," Gollin said. And any institution that "describes its couplings with IAO as a positive attribute is not to be taken seriously."}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{one source|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = World Flute Society |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = WorldFluteSocietyCurvedNameAndFluteLogo.jpg |msize = 250px |mcaption = |abbreviation = WFS |motto = Celebrating the Musical and Cultural Expressions of the World's Indigenous and Folk Flute Traditions |formation = 2013 |extinction = |type = Non-profit organization |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Lead, South Dakota]], USA |location = |region_served = |membership = 987 (2018) |language = |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Kathleen Joyce-Grendahl, DMA |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = 7 |num_volunteers = 11 |budget = |website = http://www.WorldFluteSociety.org/ |remarks = }} The '''World Flute Society''' ('''WFS'''), a successor to the '''International Native American Flute Association''', is a non-profit organization dedicated to "musical and cultural expressions of the world's indigenous and folk flute traditions."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://WorldFluteSociety.org/ |title=World Flute Society |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> WFS has a particular emphasis on the study and development of the [[Native American flute]].
Its primary activities include organizing music-oriented conferences and workshops, production of printed and audio materials, and the publication of the newsletter '''Overtones'''.
The advisory board comprises [[Mary Youngblood]], Peter Phippen, Dr. Andra Bohnet, Xavier Quijas Yxayotl of [[Guadalajara]], [[Kevin Locke (musician)|Kevin Locke]], and [[G. S. Sachdev]]. The Scholar-in-Residence is [[Coyote Oldman|Michael Graham Allen (Coyote Oldman)]].
The WFS is based in [[Suffolk, Virginia|Suffolk]], [[Virginia]], [[United States]].
==See also== *[[Native American flute]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.WorldFluteSociety.org/ World Flute Society: Official web site]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} '''Year 5''' is an educational [[year group]] in schools in many countries including [[England]], [[Wales]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. It is usually the fifth year of compulsory education and incorporates students aged between nine and eleven.
==Australia== In Australia, Year 5 is usually the fifth year of compulsory education. Although there are slight variations between the states, most children in Year 5 are aged between ten and eleven.<ref name="aus">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mceetya.edu.au/verve/_resources/Volume_1_CSSA_Final_Report.pdf|title=Cost/Benefit Analysis Relating to the Implementation of a Common School Starting Age and Associated Nomenclature by 1 January 2010|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Atelier Learning Solutions Pty Ltd|format=PDF}}</ref>
==New Zealand== In New Zealand, Year 5 is the fifth year of compulsory education. Children are aged nine or ten in this year group. <ref name="NZ">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamup.co.nz/Child/SchoolEducation/SchoolBasics/SchoolYearsAndLevels.aspx|title=School years and levels|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Ministry of Education|work=Team-up website}}</ref> Year 5 pupils are usually educated in [[Primary school]]s or in [[Area school]]s.<ref name="NZ2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamup.co.nz/Child/SchoolEducation/SchoolBasics/TypesOfSchools.aspx|title=Types of schools|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Ministry of Education|work=Team-up website}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== ===England=== In schools in [[England]] Year 5 is the fifth year after [[Reception (school)|Reception]]. It is the fifth full year of compulsory education, with children being admitted whose ninth birthday is before 1 September in any given academic year. It is also the third year of [[Key Stage 2]] in which the [[National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)|National Curriculum]] is taught.<ref name="ncuk">{{Cite web|url=http://curriculum.qca.org.uk/key-stages-1-and-2/Values-aims-and-purposes/about-the-primary-curriculum/index.aspx|title=About the primary curriculum|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Qualifications & Curriculum Authority|work=National Curriculum Website}}</ref>
Year 5 is usually the sixth year of [[primary school]] or the third year group in a [[Junior School]]. In some areas of England, Year 5 is second to final year in [[First school]].
===Wales=== In schools in [[Wales]] Year 5 is the fifth year after [[Reception (school)|Reception]]. It is currently the fifth full year of compulsory education, with children being admitted who are aged 9 before 1 September in any given academic year. It is the third year group in [[Key Stage 2]].<ref name="wales">{{Cite web|url=http://new.wales.gov.uk/topics/educationandskills/parents/whatwillchildlearn/?lang=en|title=What will your child learn? |accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Welsh Assembly Government}}</ref>
===Northern Ireland and Scotland===
In [[Northern Ireland]] and [[Scotland]], the fifth year of [[compulsory education]] is called [[Primary Five]], and pupils generally start at the age of 8 or 9.
